epidemiology.onset: Present at birth or first year of life

genetics.mutation_type: Heterozygous loss-of-function missense mutations in tyrosine kinase domain
genetics.function: VEGFR3 is essential for lymphatic vessel development (lymphangiogenesis)

presentation.location: Bilateral lower extremities, dorsum of feet characteristic
presentation.timing: Present at birth (distinguishing from lymphedema praecox)
presentation.associations: May have upturned toenails, prominent veins, hydroceles in males

diagnosis.clinical: Family history, bilateral lower extremity edema at birth, dorsal foot involvement
diagnosis.imaging: Lymphoscintigraphy shows absent or severely reduced lymphatic transport
diagnosis.differential: Turner syndrome, Noonan syndrome, other congenital syndromes

management.conservative: Complete decongestive therapy, compression garments, skin care
management.exercise: Encouraged to maintain mobility and enhance lymphatic function
management.surgical: Rarely needed; debulking or lymphovenous anastomosis in refractory cases
management.prognosis: Generally good with lifelong management; lower cellulitis risk than secondary lymphedema

definition.@value: An autosomal dominant primary lymphedema present at birth caused by mutations in the FLT4/VEGFR3 gene, characterized by bilateral lower extremity lymphedema due to hypoplastic or aplastic lymphatic vessels.

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Define Milroy disease and its genetic basis
Recognize the clinical presentation of congenital hereditary lymphedema
Understand the role of VEGFR3 in lymphatic development
Outline the management approach for primary lymphedema
clinical_pearls: Milroy disease presents AT BIRTH - this distinguishes it from lymphedema praecox (onset puberty) and tarda (>35 years)
FLT4/VEGFR3 mutation testing can confirm the diagnosis and inform genetic counseling
Despite absent lymphatics, conservative management is often highly effective
Look for associated findings: upturned toenails, prominent leg veins, hydroceles in males
Cellulitis risk is paradoxically LOWER in Milroy than secondary lymphedema
